body:
Can you try reducing that change, and see which one fixes it, e.g. by
1. deleting the local `TARGET_*` logic.
2. deleting the `sys/types.h` include.
3. moving back the `TargetConditionals.h` include to its original position.

If we know which one is causing this, we can continue figuring out why.
Sure, I can try to localize a line, tomorrow or next day.

Wonder, why you use such construct like `defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC`. See [3.8.1 Conditional inclusion](https://port70.net/~nsz/c/c89/c89-draft.html#3.8.1) - Semantics in C89:
> <...> then all remaining identifiers are replaced with 0. <...>

- If `TARGET_OS_MAC` is defined as 0: `#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` is 1 && 0 is 0
- If `TARGET_OS_MAC` is defined as 1 (not zero): `#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` is 1 && 1 is 1
- If `TARGET_OS_MAC` is undefined: `#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` is 0 && 0 (replaced) is 0.

`#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` can be reduced to `#if TARGET_OS_MAC`.

The second part `defined(TARGET_OS_OSX) && !TARGET_OS_OSX` can't be reduced and perhaps is a root error here.

According to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12132933/preprocessor-macro-for-os-x-targets, `TARGET_OS_MAC` is for all Apple platforms, not just macOS. The commit looks like it assumes `TARGET_OS_MAC` being specific to macOS, right?

> Wonder, why you use such construct like `defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC`. See [3.8.1 Conditional inclusion](https://port70.net/~nsz/c/c89/c89-draft.html#3.8.1) - Semantics in C89:
> 
> > <...> then all remaining identifiers are replaced with 0. <...>
> 
> * If `TARGET_OS_MAC` is defined as 0: `#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` is 1 && 0 is 0
> * If `TARGET_OS_MAC` is defined as 1 (not zero): `#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` is 1 && 1 is 1
> * If `TARGET_OS_MAC` is undefined: `#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` is 0 && 0 (replaced) is 0.
> 
> `#if defined(TARGET_OS_MAC) && TARGET_OS_MAC` can be reduced to `#if TARGET_OS_MAC`.

Are you saying the logic is wrong, or that it's unnecessarly verbose?

I used to fix compiler warnings when the macro is undefined and checking for its value anyway. Hence this.

> The second part `defined(TARGET_OS_OSX) && !TARGET_OS_OSX` can't be reduced and perhaps is a root error here.

My intent was to set OSX to the MAC value, if OSX was set 0, and MAC was set to non-0.

I assumed (confirmed by testing macOS builds) that MAC is a synonym for OSX. Perhaps this is wrong? llvm 18 source code sets them like this:
```
// Apple (Mac) targets.
TARGET_OS(TARGET_OS_MAC, Triple.isOSDarwin())
TARGET_OS(TARGET_OS_OSX, Triple.isMacOSX())
```

It's both "Mac", but with slight difference for the source of these values.

Can you verify how are the `TARGET_*` macros pre-defined when compiling for iOS?

`#define TARGET_OS_OSX TARGET_OS_MAC` breaks iOS build. It should not be changed from 0 to something on iOS.

See the [llvm::Triple Class Reference](https://llvm.org/doxygen/classllvm_1_1Triple.html#ab6fdf9b428bc3d57837022121c155cbf):
> ```c
> [bool](https://llvm.org/doxygen/classbool.html) llvm::Triple::isOSDarwin	(		)	const
> ```
> Is this a "Darwin" OS (macOS, **iOS**, tvOS, watchOS, XROS, or DriverKit).

So, `TARGET_OS_MAC` is always 1 for both macOS and iOS. Moreover, checking `TARGET_OS_MAC` inside `#if defined(__APPLE__)` looks redundant.

I really don't understand the change of `TARGET_OS_OSX` from 0 to 1. IMO the commit is wrong, it must not change the pre-defined `TARGET_OS_OSX`. Especially when it happens AFTER `#include <TargetConditionals.h>`. So, some system framework headers are included with `TARGET_OS_OSX` set to 0, other system framework headers are included with `TARGET_OS_OSX` set to 1. I strongly disagree with such commit and suggest that you revert it and look for other fixes for LLVM clang 18. It also might be a bug in LLVM that should be reported to them.

The problem the commit fixes is valid. The SDK (via `TargetConditionals.h`) is setting these macros wrongly for macOS given a combination of pre-defined macros, in llvm's before v18.

The fix is clearly not good in this form by interfering with iOS.

How to fix this, I don't know.

Perhaps checking for non-mac TARGET's being set would fix this, but I have no iOS SDK to test it with, and so far nobody contributed iOS CI tests to test it there.

I'm reluctant to spend more days on this just to endure more bashing, but feel free to propose a fix that doesn't break the macOS case while fixing the rest. The 3 weeks spent on macOS and the mess that is Apple and non-Apple (aka open-source) compilers, was probably the worst idea to spend my time on in my FLOSS contribution history.

Are you sure it was not an issue in the SDK 14.4 or your local? I don't get errors with the iOS and macOS SDK 14.5 if I revert that commit. This is macOS successful build dump with the reverted commit.
```
-- The CXX compiler identification is Clang 18.1.8
-- Detecting CXX compiler ABI info
-- Detecting CXX compiler ABI info - done
-- Check for working CXX compiler: /opt/homebrew/opt/llvm/bin/clang++ - skipped
-- Detecting CXX compile features
-- Detecting CXX compile features - done
-- The C compiler identification is Clang 18.1.8
-- Detecting C compiler ABI info
-- Detecting C compiler ABI info - done
-- Check for working C compiler: /opt/homebrew/opt/llvm/bin/clang - skipped
-- Detecting C compile features
-- Detecting C compile features - done

<...>

% cmake --build out/client -t libcurl_static
[29/232] Building C object third_party/zlib-ng/CMakeFiles/zlib.dir/arch/arm/arm_features.c.o
third_party/zlib-ng/arch/arm/arm_features.c:28:25: warning: a function declaration without a prototype is deprecated in all versions of C [-Wstrict-prototypes]
   28 | static int arm_has_crc32() {
      |                         ^
      |                          void
1 warning generated.
[226/232] Building C object third_party/curl/lib/CMakeFiles/libcurl_static.dir/vtls/sectransp.c.o
third_party/curl/lib/vtls/sectransp.c:2626:6: warning: variable 'nread' may be uninitialized when used here [-Wconditional-uninitialized]
 2626 |   if(nread > 0) {
      |      ^~~~~
third_party/curl/lib/vtls/sectransp.c:2577:16: note: initialize the variable 'nread' to silence this warning
 2577 |   ssize_t nread;
      |                ^
      |                 = 0
1 warning generated.
[232/232] Linking C static library Debug/libcurl-d.a
```
Maybe it was similar manipulations with pre-defined macros in your project, and the issue is there and irrelevant to curl, macOS SDK, LLVM-18.

No, it's not a corrupt copy on my local system. I've first seen it in CI, using the SDK and llvm@15 compiler pre-installed on the GHA macos runner image. I've included the link to the CI log line where it happened in the commit message.

It needs the open-source llvm compiler, any version earlier than v18.

My assessment could be wrong, but the error is not.

edit: it's also not a manipulation in my project.

Ok, LLVM-15 fails. Then this is LLVM-15 issue and should be solved with `target_compile_definitions(libcurl PRIVATE TARGET_OS_OSX=1)` or whatever in CMakeLists.txt if LLVM-15 is detected on macOS. Changing OS specific macros in curl is a wrong solution - user code gets `TARGET_OS_OSX 1` if it includes "curl/curl.h" and gets `TARGET_OS_OSX 0` if it does not include "curl/curl.h" - that may result in hard bugs in user projects.

Tested it, only LLVM-15 is buggy. LLVM-14 and LLVM-16 work well.

It has nothing to do with CMake. It's also not an issue with llvm@15, but with llvm < 18. The build system cannot set such macro, because it would apply to all Apple targets, not just macOS ones.

It's also not an llvm bug: llvm cannot predict that N years after its release, Apple decides that its next SDK release will no longer work correctly unless the standard C compiler pre-defines some newly invented macros.

edit: ...and guess in advance, that Apple's future SDK will fail to fallback gracefully, when their newly invented pre-defined macro is missing.

issue.title: macos: fix Apple SDK bug workaround for non-macOS targets

labels.name: appleOS
labels.description: specific to an Apple operating system

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
Turns out that MAC != OSX, despite what these names otherwise mean and
what's suggested by source code comments. "MAC" in fact means Darwin
(aka Apple), not macOS. "OSX" means macOS.

GitHub bumped the macos-14 runner default to Xcode 15.4, hitting the
llvm@15 incompatibility bug by default. Meaning the previous workaround
for the SDK bug is necessary.

This patch extend the workaround to not apply to mobile OS variants.

Follow-up to ff784af461175584c73e7e2b65af00b1a5a6f67f #14159
Fixes #14269
Closes #14275

---

CI fails without ff784af461175584c73e7e2b65af00b1a5a6f67f in place:
https://github.com/curl/curl/actions/runs/10102407245

issue.title: Update to vanilla curl 8.9.0
